What's more, this behavior perpetuates the idea that the internet is a place where negative behavior is accepted and even encouraged. It is a reminder that the anonymity of the internet can bring out the worst in people, and that the behavior of individuals on 4chan is not representative of the online community as a whole.

In conclusion, the fact that 4chan trolls are counting down the days until Avatar 3 is released is a sad reflection of the state of internet culture. It is a reminder that while the internet can be a place of creativity and positivity, it can also be a breeding ground for negativity and harmful behavior. We should all strive to create a better online community by promoting positivity and discouraging negative behavior. Moreover, we should also critically examine the media we consume and the messages they perpetuate.

The video says it all, really. Star Trek was always the purvey of nerds. Yes, it was entry-level nerdity, and TNG was popular enough to rise from the sea of nerdity into the mainstream, but if you professed to liking Star Trek up to the early 2000's people would automatically assume you were a nerd. And for the most part, they would be correct. And this was because Star Trek was imaginative, hopeful, and smart. Most of the time, at least.

But the reputation of intelligence connected with nerd stuff was commodified sometime after the early 2000's. Remember all those vicious media articles about how you can't identify someone superficially associating with your hobby as a "fake geek"? Well, this is the end result. Modern Trek is washing machine television that exists solely for a gormless audience that wants the reputation associated with the name, but without actually having to watch something that doesn't give instant gratification and confirms their base beliefs at every turn. As someone I know once put it "I like Discovery better because it's more action and less talking".

A video game doesn't need to have any goal or explicit win-state. We've seen that with the rise of walking simulators, which are no different than experiencing a piece of architecture, a garden, or an art exhibit itself.

>N-no shut up you're wrong, films will always be better because they are creative and show artistic expression!!!?1!!! I'm right your wrong!!!!

If video games are not expressions of human creative skill and imagination, then nothing can be called “art” any more. Not only are games in general such expressions in themselves, they also inspire imagination and enthuse creative expression. Some games even demand these things in order to be played.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>180356813
His entire point was that video games can't be art because they're interactive, and thus it's impossible to truly experience an artist's vision. I consider this to be a flawed premise, because ultimately it's not the artist vision that creates the experience we call "art" in the observer, it's what that observer experiences. There are plenty of pieces that were intended as art, but not perceived as such. And there is plenty of contention about what constitutes art even among observers of identical pieces, including in Ebert's own field. Starship Troopers famously flew over his big, dumb head, for instance. The argument also fails to account for the fact that the interactive experience is taken into account by the artist, and that many modern art pieces that are universally recognized as art have interactive components. Also, the opinion of an unadultered artist's vision is somewhat snooty. The products in his own field are guaranteed to never be the vision of just one artist. Even Neil Breen finds it impossible to make movies entirely on his own, and Lord knows he tries.

In short, he's wrong because his premise was flawed.

>>180341765
It's really really bad. Until you get to the second season which is much much worse and makes you think that the first season was ok.

Basically it's nothing at all like TNG. There's no hopeful future utopia, cities are portrayed as contemporary urban hellholes like in Cyberpunk, Bladerunner, Altered Carbon, The Expanse, or Star Wars PT. Hives of degeneracy, dimly lit clubs with neon lights etc. There's no harmonious balance between man and nature in the construction of the cities as you would expect from a true utopic future society.

It's a serial, meaning it follows a single story arc across the entire season. The story is poor and the dialogue aside from Picard's is terrible (until the second season when even Picard starts making rudimentary grammatical errors e.g. "my mother was hung").

The only good parts in season 1 are the beginning at the Picard vineyard and the episode where they meet Riker because at least that was in a comfy inthewoods settings. The second season has one saving grace, which is Q, who carries the entire season hard, but everything else is really bad.

>>180341765
Here's the actual verdict, and not the fandom menace sadcow bloo bloo opinion

>Picard S1
Decent follow-up to Nemesis and frantic attempt to make something out of ST09's loose ends (Romulus suddenly blowing up). A lot of the decent backstory is explained off-camera in a novel, and the show picks up after a lot of the interesting stuff has already happened.
>The Good: Better end to Data's arc than whatever Nemesis tried to do, has an interesting development for the Borg, the new captain and his crew of EMH's is pretty fun.
>The Bad: Mass Effect rip-off threat and Picard acts out of character often. Paced too slowly when it ultimately just wants to be a sci-fi action show.

>Picard S2
The COVID season. Has a pretty good first two episodes and then drops the ball into the abyss as the production films entirely in COVID-safe modern day Los Angeles locations. Shocking lack of commitment to characters and stories from S1 being resolved, directionless plot and stretched far too thin. John DeLancie does what he can, and if anything in this season works, it's his final scene with Picard.
>The Good: Q's final scene. First two episodes are relatively fun.
>The Bad: Absolutely everything else.

>Picard S3
Only seen the first six episodes. This is the season that's most similar to what fans were wanting. Similar in look and tone to the TNG movies, but with deeper plots similar to TNG itself. Lots of follow-up to DS9 in particular. Straightforward plot that doesn't meander like S2, but has a lot more importance to its characters which S1 and S2 lacked.
>The Good: Finally gets the characters right, lots of starship porn.
>The Bad: Has to keep some lingering elements from S1 and S2 and doesn't work them in well.

Cheap, generic sci-fi sets throw together without care, plot that insists on being overarching to the entire setting so you can't ignore it in the canon, petty characters who are constantly, constantly bickering with each other, retroactively changing the history of major characters.

Imagine you're a kid, and you tell your parents you want a dog. So your drunk of a father comes home one day with a disgusting, legless pile of suffering. "here ya go, ya little shit. walk him every day". That's Discovery and Picard.

Per a 2014 interview with Rolling Stone, Martin began writing what would become A Game of Thrones in 1991 — a year that started with the Giants winning the Super Bowl against the Buffalo Bills. It would be five more years before the book was ready for publication, during which the Giants made a brief two-game appearance in the January 1994 playoffs and the Jets also made a rare playoffs appearance in the wild card round in ’91, so there was a lot of wind in Martin’s sails.

A Clash of Kings was published in the U.S. in 1999, a year that also saw the Jets make the playoffs (a running theme in the NFL for decades has been the Jets being god-awful, even worse than the Giants, so this was a Big Deal). November 2000, when A Storm of Swords was published in the U.S., doesn’t seem that remarkable for New York football, but the Giants were well on their way to a pretty great playoff run that season, going all the way to the Super Bowl against the Baltimore Ravens in January 2001. (They lost that time, which is kind of fitting for A Storm of Swords’ general themes.)

A Feast for Crows wouldn’t see the light of day until fall 2005, a four-year stretch where New York’s NFL playoff record was a bit fallow, rarely rising above the initial wild card round — but the Jets did scrape past that only to lose in the division round against the Pittsburgh Steelers in, you guessed it, January 2005.

The Giants win the Super Bowl again in 2008 but A Dance With Dragons does not arrive until 2011 — a truly remarkable year for New York football. The Jets, for the second year in a row, had their best playoff showing since 1998, and the Giants began their march to winning the Super Bowl in early 2012 — a 12-month period of ecstasy for New York football, and ASOIAF fans.

/sp/artans how are we doing?

This movie confuses me.

Why are these two people even friends, first of all? They're obviously extremely different. And if you think the other guy's an absolute idiot, why'd you make him your best friend? Is he the only friendly one on the island? What connected them? I don't buy it.

And I don't get why the fat guy's so hellbent on not wanting to talk to Colin Farrell. Like, the premise of having to cut someone off to advance your own self-development is a great thing to explore, but here, it just fizzles out about halfway through the movie once the fat guy starts cutting his own fingers, because suddenly, the movie's no longer about that premise. Instead, it becomes some ham-fisted game of who gets to be the most self-destructive, biggest asshole.

Where is the psychological realism? They suggest that the fat guy's depressed/despairing but he sure doesn't act like it. They seem like ahistorical figures being told what to do and say with puppet strings. And where's the plot? This felt like watching a play than an actual movie.

I haven't watched the film so I can't comment on the plot and characters, but I can tell you from first hand experience that losing interest in a friend is extremely real.
I know this one guy whom we can call Jimmy for the sakes of this post. Jimmy and myself are 30 and 28 respectively and we met in Elementary School. A little later in life, we would hang out after school, mostly either play videogames at one of our house's or talk about them. When the time came, he went to one high school but I went to another. Due to this we slowly drifted away which is quite natural, but he was really fucking fighting it and I didn't mind at the time. Both met loads of new people but at the end of the day, I'd be his shoulder to cry on and I even felt "proud", in a very vain and self centered way. However, I soon came to the realization that Jimmy and myself had shared no interests other than videogames. And every topic of conversation was a videogame. As he started a job and I was getting ready for college, it dawned on me how incredibly dull most of the conversations we had were and are. I went to college to a different state altogether but this didn't stop Jimmy from texting me all the time about some random bullshit. I'd take days to respond to let him implicitly know that I don't want to talk about it. Then later on I would even tell him that I don't want to do that. Yet Jimmy persisted.
Last time the two of us went for drinks or anywhere really was more than 5 years ago. Yet still he texts me random jokes and videogame puns that the two of us loved 15 years ago. I sometimes take a month to answer. Somewhat recently my birthday came and he texted me "happy birthday my guy, hope you have an excellent one, hope you get to fuck bitches left and right haha" (I have a long term girlfriend) and follows that up with "really wish you were back in our hometown, it'd be really cool to hang out like we did in the old days haha :)".

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's the easiest fucking anime to understand.

A boy is abandoned by his father who only uses him as a tool. The boy is emotionally stunted, has no support and is asked to perform dangerous feats for little to no reward or recognition. He's constantly traumatized throughout the show, and Japanese society doesn't view mental health as anything other than weakness, so they push him harder.

Little did he realize that it was all planned. Human instrumentality was to fuse humanity into a single being of ultimate power. Like a hivemind, within a single organism. There would be no barriers between people and no judgement.
But shinji was purposely bred to hate this concept. He has little to no identity, and opening up is his greatest fear as nerv was guided to push him deeper into his shell.
So when Shinji was given the choice of completing human instrumentality, although most people would say sure, shinji said no. This sets off a series of events for gendo to bring back his wife.

Shinji just wanted someone who wouldn't judge him, someone who would love him unconditionally like his mother. Gendo made sure he never had that. It was an experiment to create a person who would never trust anyone.

Shinji isn't weak. He's a normal human with zero support. People who think they can do a dangerous job while everyone pesters and mistreats you obviously missed the point of exhausting it can be.

When the progenitor alien race seeded Earth they accidentally sent two. The first seed (White Moon) contained the Angels which are the primary antagonists of the series. The second seed (Black Moon) contained the ancestors of humans. The First Impact occurred when the unintended Black Moon impacted on Earth and suppressed the awakening of the Angels from the White Moon. The whole reason the Angels want to control the third impact was to eradicate the human race and reclaim the Earth as their birthright.

>Asuka was trained from a young age to be a pilot
>her pilot facade began to crumble
That's true, and I don't really like their character arcs. Asuka starts as a confident pilot, but begins to question her self worth - and then totally loses it in the Rebuilds. Shinji is the opposite: starts as a total loser, but (too) slowly begins to accept his self worth.

I've always identified more with Asuka, and it really feels like her part in the story is robbed, because she's the active person, yet doesn't get rewarded for it. Shinji, on the other hand, gets rewarded simply for having the "epiphany" that he too is a regular person, just like everyone else.

>Every other moment the kids are in control of the machine.
Technically, yes. But to me it has always felt like the pilots are more like "keys", who unlock the (restrained) EVAs. They need a "soul" inside them to function, but the pilots don't really need to operate them that much.

It's always made sense to me but I've seen it more as Asuka is extrinsically motivated where as Shinji is intrinsically motivated. The reference to Asuka and the doll is important because a doll is hollow just like Asuka's sense of self is. She only knows what she's been told by others in that she's a 'wunderkind' and pilot. That's why she's always comparing herself to others and when Shinji becomes her equal as a pilot in the series (Although I'd say her realisation in EoE and fight with the MP Eva's shows that she was the better pilot) she falls apart. She has no inner core to fall back on. Shinji however has formed an internal working model in his solitude, a flawed one that contains multiple conflicting ideals but it allows him to make his own decisions outside of others. Asuka's journey in the series is self discovery where as Shinji's is coming to terms with/healing the self.

Shinji in the first episode is on autopilot at first. He's summoned to NERV and thrust immediately into one of the most important positions on the planet which completely overwhelms him. However, he still refuses to pilot the EVA initially despite all of the pressure put on him. In episode 4 when he runs away for the first time he says to himself that he needs to go back. These don't happen because of what other people say to him but because he has the conflicting rationales of keeping himself from harm's way and a sense of duty to others. Even though it's fundamentally flawed and annoying to watch it shows the internal processes going on in Shinji. Any time some is giving advice to Shinji it doesn't actually change his mind, it simply illuminates a POV he already has.
>It should be, but I just don't see it in the show.
Asuka definitely gets the short end of the stick with regard to development near the end. We see her lack of esteem and where that comes from but her development is shoved into a single scene in EoE which was always disappointing. I think the biggest example of the very final scene of EoE. The experience of instrumentality has changed her and made her more compassionate. I couldn't imagine early series Asuka reacting the same way as she does in that scene.

>>180340698
Up to interpretation but I think the shock and intrinsic terror of being an individual cut off from others and having to fear what they're thinking of you, that irreducible uncertainty, it freaks him out to the point he tries to kill this other person, lashing out at the nature of being seperate people. Her moment of attempted connection and tenderness, the closest thing to an antidote to the nature of separateness within normal human life, is what dissuades him and brings him to his senses.

Asuka's "disgusting" or "feels disgusting" seems to always be taken to be referring to Shinji. And this might be the case, hammering home that attempts at connection and love go hand in hand with thinking negative thoughts about each other-it's an unavoidable reality. Even people who love you will often not think about you in an entirely positive way or entirely on your terms. But I actually think she might be referring to being back in her own body as an individual person after instrumentality. After this holy disembodied half-alive one-ness, it actually feels literally gross and wrong to be an indifvidual person in a single body.
